data.title: renderer: fix font glyph memory allocations
data.body: Fixes the memtype mismatch crash of #884.

data.title: make pxdgen loads voltron
data.body:
I've got a very strange bug, pending investigation.
[`voltron`](https://github.com/snare/voltron) is a gdb plugin i use in my `.gdbinit`.
I really wonder how this ends up in the backtrace. It then imports `gdb`, which is my custom file, which crashes.

Running voltron in `pxdgen` is definitely wrong, and the backtrace indicates pygments somehow loads it?

```
make --no-print-directory -C bin pxdgen
[100%] pxdgen: generating .pxd files from headers
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/runpy.py", line 193, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", mod_spec)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "/home/jj/devel/openage/buildsystem/pxdgen.py", line 436, in <module>
    main()
  File "/home/jj/devel/openage/buildsystem/pxdgen.py", line 428, in main
    print_warnings=True
  File "/home/jj/devel/openage/buildsystem/pxdgen.py", line 352, in generate
    result = "\n".join(self.get_pxd_lines())
  File "/home/jj/devel/openage/buildsystem/pxdgen.py", line 258, in get_pxd_lines
    self.parse()
  File "/home/jj/devel/openage/buildsystem/pxdgen.py", line 215, in parse
    for token, val in self.tokenize():
  File "/home/jj/devel/openage/buildsystem/pxdgen.py", line 72, in tokenize
    lexer = get_lexer_for_filename('.cpp')
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/pygments/lexers/__init__.py", line 203, in get_lexer_for_filename
    res = find_lexer_class_for_filename(_fn, code)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/pygments/lexers/__init__.py", line 168, in find_lexer_class_for_filename
    for cls in find_plugin_lexers():
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/pygments/plugin.py", line 53, in find_plugin_lexers
    yield entrypoint.load()
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2303, in load
    return self.resolve()
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2309, in resolve
    module = __import__(self.module_name, fromlist=['__name__'], level=0)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/voltron/__init__.py", line 95, in <module>
    setup_env()
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/voltron/__init__.py", line 31, in setup_env
    pkg_plugins=PluginDirectory('plugins', parent=PackageDirectory())
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/scruffy/env.py", line 47, in __init__
    self.add(**kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/scruffy/env.py", line 112, in add
    self._children[key].prepare()
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/scruffy/file.py", line 437, in prepare
    self.load()
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/scruffy/file.py", line 443, in load
    self._pm.load_plugins(self.path)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/scruffy/plugin.py", line 65, in load_plugins
    self.load_plugins(filepath)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/scruffy/plugin.py", line 61, in load_plugins
    mod = imp.load_module(modname, file, path, descr)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/imp.py", line 234, in load_module
    return load_source(name, filename, file)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/imp.py", line 172, in load_source
    module = _load(spec)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/site-packages/voltron/plugins/debugger/dbg_gdb.py", line 14, in <module>
    import gdb
  File "/home/jj/devel/openage/gdb.py", line 4, in <module>
    class WatchBlBr(gdb.Breakpoint):
AttributeError: module 'gdb' has no attribute 'Breakpoint'

```

data.title: Support and document debugging with gdbgui
data.body:
I figured out how to debug libopenage with gdbgui. It is a browser-based frontend to gdb built with Python and JavaScript.

gdbgui: https://github.com/cs01/gdbgui

This PR:
- Add a .gdbinit (gdb commands) to debug openage and break at main.cpp
- Document how to debug openage and how to do this with gdbgui

![gdbgui3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7106652/29496931-e0b5dc7c-85dd-11e7-9327-fd8ccf2682e2.png)

data.title: doc: Update DRS file format.
data.body:
Internally, Age of Empires does something like this when reading files
from a DRS archive:

```c
read_drs_file('bina', 50500);
```

Note how it uses a C char with multiple bytes. This is stored on disk as a
little-endian integer, so the 'a' byte ends up at the lowest address,
and the 'b' byte ends up at the highest address. Hence why it appears
to be reversed.

The "magical byte" is simply a padding space ' ' character or the final 'a' of
the "bina" file type.

data.title: Arch Linux package & insecure RPATH
data.body:
Hi, some time ago I have adopted the AUR pkgbuild of Openage because it was orphaned and failed to install

It would be nice if you write that can be installed with "yaourt -S openage-git" or equivalent for Arch & derivates

I haven't tested yet the program because of issue #788 

Analyzing the package with [namcap](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Namcap) give me this result:

> $ namcap openage-git-v0.3.0.r980.g9661a697-1-x86_64.pkg.tar.xz
openage-git E: Insecure RPATH '/home/lolix/Dev/Github/PKGBUILD/openage-git/src/openage/build/libopenage' in file ('usr/bin/openage')

data.title: Address sanitizer false positives.
data.body:
when compiling dea5112dbd with addresssanitizer, I get the following error. It looks like a false positive to me, but I don't know who is responsible for it.

data.title: doc/building: add gentoo
data.body: (not to mention this was the first distro to have packaged openage...)

data.title: readme: add contact table at the top
data.body: Fixes #881

data.title: Add our new blog to readme
data.body:
We now have a fancy blog: https://blog.openage.sft.mx/

We must add that to the README so people can find it :)

- Integrate the Windows build instructions properly in the documentation.

Kindly notify me of other updates required in the documentation. I can try to address those in this PR.

data.title: [WIP] doc: Network protocol of AoC 1.0c
data.body:
**EDIT:** Screw it! Let this PR be a (full) documentation of the network communication in AoC.

Motivation: Revealing otherwise hidden mechanics in the game engine, understanding the implementation of other game mechanics, determining what can lead to an out-of-sync error. Could result in finding a lot of ridiculous bugs.

- [x] General structure
- [x] Protocol headers
- [ ] Synchronization
    - [ ] In-game Sync 
    - [ ] Lobby
- [ ] Chat Messaging (already in repo)
    - [ ] Spoofing and forging messages
- [x] Player-issued commands
    - [x] Unit interaction
        - [x] Primary actions
        - [x] Movement
        - [x] Formations
    - [x] Unit creation
    - [x] Buildings
    - [x] Market
    - [x] Others
        - [x] Tribute
        - [x] Diplomacy
        - [x] Flares
    - [x] AI actions

Things for later PRs:
* AI actions refined
The AI is a pain to test which leads to action `0x1f` being mostly unknown bytes
* Wireshark dissector
who wouldn't want this?
* C structs
If we or someone else would want to use this protocol, for whatever reason.

data.title: fslike test broken for case-insensitive filesystems
data.body:
Windows filesystems and apparently some mac systems (#874) have case insensitive filesystems.

Our `fslike` system was built for case-sensitive filesystems like Linux has.
So we have a test in `openage/util/fslike/test.py` that assumes the underlying filesystem is case-sensitive: It checks that when just an `a` is created, then an `A` is created and redirected to be the same `a`, and then we test if only `a` exists and not `A`, as `A` was redirected to `a`.

If now the underlying filesystem is case-insensitive, it will report that `A` and `a` exist, which breaks the test.

Solution: test if the underlying filesystem is case sensitive or not and adjust the test to expect different results then.

data.title: Accessibility modes
data.body:
Apparently about 10 % of gamers have some kind of disability, so we should start to think about making the game accessible for them. AoE 2 was already very progressive in this regard, but the HD Edition so far does little to implement the "Lessons Learned" that were discovered in the 17 years after the initial release.

We are already addressing many of these issues with changeable font size and such, but there's so much more. Especially color blind mode is vital for distinguishing multiplayer factions.

References:
* [List of accessibility modes with best practice examples](http://gameaccessibilityguidelines.com/full-list)
* [A practical guide to game accessibility](https://www.includification.com/AbleGamers_Includification.pdf) by Able Gamers with descriptions on what disabled people find difficult.
* [Article about good and bad implementations of color blind modes](http://www.gamersexperience.com/colorblind-accessibility-in-video-games-is-the-industry-heading-in-the-right-direction/)
* [Extra Credits: Accessibility - The Curb Cut Effect](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PJoax1Z1x4Y)

data.title: Troubleshooting Guide
data.body: Made a troubleshooting guide for questions that were asked all the time.

data.title: Mouse controlled window movement doesnt turn off when window is out of focus
data.body:
Because of #843 the visible frame will move into (Gaben) oblivion when you Alt-Tab or minimize the window. Trying to find the map again turns out to be very difficult.

Solution:
* Turn mouse controlled window movement off when the game is out of focus
* Define boundaries for the camera so it cannot "escape"

data.title: Windows native support using MSVC - Visual Studio 2017
data.body:
A step towards #9.
Fixes #508 with a modification - VS2017 instead of VS2015.
Supersedes #582 (credits to @YellowOnion).

<del>
## The procedure (this is here for my recollection later)
- Get the dependencies using `vcpkg`.
- Build/install the missing dependency `opusfile` manually.
- Copy `dirent.h` from `vcpkg`'s downloads directory - it's named `fontconfig-dirent.h`.
- Build using CMake - the usual workflow.
- Install the `DejaVu Serif Book` font and copy the configuration to the fontconfig directory.
- Modify the environment variables required to make the program run (hacks required before proper packaging).
</del>

## A summary of the changes
- A majority of the changes are for selectively compiling some code using preprocessor macros `_MSC_VER` or `_WIN32`. The former for MSVC specific code, and the latter if it is applicable to other compilers on Windows also.
- Introduction of ~~`LIBOPENAGE_API`~~`OAAPI` for decorating the DLL's entry points for Windows. `__declspec(dllexport)` when compiling the DLL's sources, `__declspec(dllimport)` for the code including the header files only - the API user.
  - Added an introduction in `doc/code/pyinterface.md`.
- ~~**[Disrupting change]** In `libopenage/error/error.h`, the variadic macro `ENSURE` has been changed to a two-argument macro. I left a `TODO` - kindly respond with the approach to choose here.~~
- Python changes are mostly for path handling - the native path separator for Windows is a `'\\'` (weird, agreed).
- CMake changes include path handling, finding dependent libraries and packages.
- **[Coordinate system hacks]** The macros CONCAT and LOOP retain their variadic implementation, with the condition that they have a smaller arguments supported limit (3 for both). This should be superseded by the coordinate system overhaul in #662.
- `libopenage/error/stackanalyzer.cpp` contains the skeleton code for #479. Without #480 though, I don't expect it to provide a lot of useful information. The change includes a bug-fix in the GNU execinfo section.
- Included `ciso646` which provides the expansion for `and`, `or`, `not`, `xor`, etc.
- Added a document describing the build instructions: `doc/build_instructions/windows_msvc.md`.

I've left a bunch of `TODO`s and `HACK`s around in the code. I can try to address the critical ones pointed out by the reviewers, the rest can be addressed subsequently.
I've built the project on Windows (using MSVC) only. I'll rely on the CI reports for other platforms (apologies for the cache thrashing). Please let me know if I need to run some test manually.

data.title: units can get removed before on_complete runs
data.body: Minor correction to last pr. Using the pointer to target unit in on_completion() is not a good idea, they may already be removed. Instead pass id of the type.

data.title: Fixed spelling mistake in README
data.body: Changed "und" to "and".
